text: ﻿CHAPTER I. Mrs. Rachel Lynde Is Surprised
label: surprise

text: MRS. Rachel Lynde lived just where the Avonlea main road dipped down into a little hollow, fringed with alders and ladies’ eardrops and traversed by a brook that had its source away back in the woods of the old Cuthbert place; it was reputed to be an intricate, headlong brook in its earlier course through those woods, with dark secrets of pool and cascade; but by the time it reached Lynde’s Hollow it was a quiet, well-conducted little stream, for not even a brook could run past Mrs. Rachel Lynde’s door without due regard for decency and decorum; it probably was conscious that Mrs. Rachel was sitting at her window, keeping a sharp eye on everything that passed, from brooks and children up, and that if she noticed anything odd or out of place she would never rest until she had ferreted out the whys and wherefores thereof.
label: neutral

text: There are plenty of people, in Avonlea and out of it, who can attend closely to their neighbors’ business by dint of neglecting their own; but Mrs. Rachel Lynde was one of those capable creatures who can manage their own concerns and those of other folks into the bargain.
label: neutral

text: She was a notable housewife; her work was always done and well done; she “ran” the Sewing Circle, helped run the Sunday-school, and was the strongest prop of the Church Aid Society and Foreign Missions Auxiliary.
label: neutral

text: Yet with all this Mrs. Rachel found abundant time to sit for hours at her kitchen window, knitting “cotton warp” quilts--she had knitted sixteen of them, as Avonlea housekeepers were wont to tell in awed voices--and keeping a sharp eye on the main road that crossed the hollow and wound up the steep red hill beyond.
label: fear

text: Since Avonlea occupied a little triangular peninsula jutting out into the Gulf of St. Lawrence, with water on two sides of it, anybody who went out of it or into it had to pass over that hill road and so run the unseen gauntlet of Mrs. Rachel’s all-seeing eye.
label: fear

text: She was sitting there one afternoon in early June.
label: neutral

text: The sun was coming in at the window warm and bright; the orchard on the slope below the house was in a bridal flush of pinky-white bloom, hummed over by a myriad of bees.
label: neutral

text: Thomas Lynde--a meek little man whom Avonlea people called “Rachel Lynde’s husband”--was sowing his late turnip seed on the hill field beyond the barn; and Matthew Cuthbert ought to have been sowing his on the big red brook field away over by Green Gables.
label: joy

text: Mrs. Rachel knew that he ought because she had heard him tell Peter Morrison the evening before in William J. Blair’s store over at Carmody that he meant to sow his turnip seed the next afternoon.
label: neutral

text: Peter had asked him, of course, for Matthew Cuthbert had never been known to volunteer information about anything in his whole life.
label: neutral

text: And yet here was Matthew Cuthbert, at half-past three on the afternoon of a busy day, placidly driving over the hollow and up the hill; moreover, he wore a white collar and his best suit of clothes, which was plain proof that he was going out of Avonlea; and he had the buggy and the sorrel mare, which betokened that he was going a considerable distance.
label: neutral

text: Now, where was Matthew Cuthbert going and why was he going there?
label: surprise

text: Had it been any other man in Avonlea, Mrs. Rachel, deftly putting this and that together, might have given a pretty good guess as to both questions.
label: neutral

text: But Matthew so rarely went from home that it must be something pressing and unusual which was taking him; he was the shyest man alive and hated to have to go among strangers or to any place where he might have to talk.
label: fear

text: Matthew, dressed up with a white collar and driving in a buggy, was something that didn’t happen often.
label: neutral

text: Mrs. Rachel, ponder as she might, could make nothing of it and her afternoon’s enjoyment was spoiled.
label: neutral

text: “I’ll just step over to Green Gables after tea and find out from Marilla where he’s gone and why,” the worthy woman finally concluded.
label: neutral

text: “He doesn’t generally go to town this time of year and he _never_ visits; if he’d run out of turnip seed he wouldn’t dress up and take the buggy to go for more; he wasn’t driving fast enough to be going for a doctor.
label: neutral

text: Yet something must have happened since last night to start him off.
label: neutral

text: I’m clean puzzled, that’s what, and I won’t know a minute’s peace of mind or conscience until I know what has taken Matthew Cuthbert out of Avonlea today.”
label: surprise

text: Accordingly after tea Mrs. Rachel set out; she had not far to go; the big, rambling, orchard-embowered house where the Cuthberts lived was a scant quarter of a mile up the road from Lynde’s Hollow.
label: neutral

text: To be sure, the long lane made it a good deal further.
label: neutral

text: Matthew Cuthbert’s father, as shy and silent as his son after him, had got as far away as he possibly could from his fellow men without actually retreating into the woods when he founded his homestead.
label: fear

text: Green Gables was built at the furthest edge of his cleared land and there it was to this day, barely visible from the main road along which all the other Avonlea houses were so sociably situated.
label: neutral

text: Mrs. Rachel Lynde did not call living in such a place _living_ at all.
label: neutral

text: “It’s just _staying_, that’s what,” she said as she stepped along the deep-rutted, grassy lane bordered with wild rose bushes.
label: neutral

text: “It’s no wonder Matthew and Marilla are both a little odd, living away back here by themselves.
label: neutral

text: Trees aren’t much company, though dear knows if they were there’d be enough of them.
label: neutral

text: I’d ruther look at people.
label: disgust

text: To be sure, they seem contented enough; but then, I suppose, they’re used to it.
label: joy

text: A body can get used to anything, even to being hanged, as the Irishman said.”
label: disgust

text: With this Mrs. Rachel stepped out of the lane into the backyard of Green Gables.
label: fear

text: Very green and neat and precise was that yard, set about on one side with great patriarchal willows and on the other with prim Lombardies.
label: neutral

text: Not a stray stick nor stone was to be seen, for Mrs. Rachel would have seen it if there had been.
label: neutral

text: Privately she was of the opinion that Marilla Cuthbert swept that yard over as often as she swept her house.
label: neutral

text: One could have eaten a meal off the ground without overbrimming the proverbial peck of dirt.
label: disgust

text: Mrs. Rachel rapped smartly at the kitchen door and stepped in when bidden to do so.
label: neutral

text: The kitchen at Green Gables was a cheerful apartment--or would have been cheerful if it had not been so painfully clean as to give it something of the appearance of an unused parlor.
label: joy

text: Its windows looked east and west; through the west one, looking out on the back yard, came a flood of mellow June sunlight; but the east one, whence you got a glimpse of the bloom white cherry-trees in the left orchard and nodding, slender birches down in the hollow by the brook, was greened over by a tangle of vines.
label: neutral

text: Here sat Marilla Cuthbert, when she sat at all, always slightly distrustful of sunshine, which seemed to her too dancing and irresponsible a thing for a world which was meant to be taken seriously; and here she sat now, knitting, and the table behind her was laid for supper.
label: fear

text: Mrs. Rachel, before she had fairly closed the door, had taken a mental note of everything that was on that table.
label: neutral

text: There were three plates laid, so that Marilla must be expecting some one home with Matthew to tea; but the dishes were everyday dishes and there was only crab-apple preserves and one kind of cake, so that the expected company could not be any particular company.
label: neutral

text: Yet what of Matthew’s white collar and the sorrel mare?
label: neutral

text: Mrs. Rachel was getting fairly dizzy with this unusual mystery about quiet, unmysterious Green Gables.
label: fear

text: “Good evening, Rachel,” Marilla said briskly.
label: joy

text: “This is a real fine evening, isn’t it?
label: neutral

text: Won’t you sit down?
label: anger

text: How are all your folks?”
label: surprise

text: Something that for lack of any other name might be called friendship existed and always had existed between Marilla Cuthbert and Mrs. Rachel, in spite of--or perhaps because of--their dissimilarity.
label: neutral

text: Marilla was a tall, thin woman, with angles and without curves; her dark hair showed some gray streaks and was always twisted up in a hard little knot behind with two wire hairpins stuck aggressively through it.
label: neutral

text: She looked like a woman of narrow experience and rigid conscience, which she was; but there was a saving something about her mouth which, if it had been ever so slightly developed, might have been considered indicative of a sense of humor.
label: neutral

text: “We’re all pretty well,” said Mrs. Rachel.
label: neutral

text: “I was kind of afraid _you_ weren’t, though, when I saw Matthew starting off today.
label: fear

text: I thought maybe he was going to the doctor’s.”
label: neutral

text: Marilla’s lips twitched understandingly.
label: neutral

text: She had expected Mrs. Rachel up; she had known that the sight of Matthew jaunting off so unaccountably would be too much for her neighbor’s curiosity.
label: fear

text: “Oh, no, I’m quite well although I had a bad headache yesterday,” she said.
label: neutral

text: “Matthew went to Bright River.
label: neutral

text: We’re getting a little boy from an orphan asylum in Nova Scotia and he’s coming on the train tonight.”
label: neutral

text: If Marilla had said that Matthew had gone to Bright River to meet a kangaroo from Australia Mrs. Rachel could not have been more astonished.
label: surprise

text: She was actually stricken dumb for five seconds.
label: disgust

text: It was unsupposable that Marilla was making fun of her, but Mrs. Rachel was almost forced to suppose it.
label: disgust

text: “Are you in earnest, Marilla?” she demanded when voice returned to her.
label: neutral

text: “Yes, of course,” said Marilla, as if getting boys from orphan asylums in Nova Scotia were part of the usual spring work on any well-regulated Avonlea farm instead of being an unheard of innovation.
label: neutral

text: Mrs. Rachel felt that she had received a severe mental jolt.
label: sadness

text: She thought in exclamation points.
label: neutral

text: A boy!
label: surprise

text: Marilla and Matthew Cuthbert of all people adopting a boy!
label: surprise

text: From an orphan asylum!
label: surprise

text: Well, the world was certainly turning upside down!
label: surprise

text: She would be surprised at nothing after this!
label: surprise

text: Nothing!
label: surprise

text: “What on earth put such a notion into your head?” she demanded disapprovingly.
label: disgust

text: This had been done without her advice being asked, and must perforce be disapproved.
label: anger

text: “Well, we’ve been thinking about it for some time--all winter in fact,”  returned Marilla.
label: neutral

text: “Mrs.
label: neutral

text: Alexander Spencer was up here one day before Christmas and she said she was going to get a little girl from the asylum over in Hopeton in the spring.
label: neutral

text: Her cousin lives there and Mrs. Spencer has visited her and knows all about it.
label: neutral

text: So Matthew and I have talked it over off and on ever since.
label: neutral

text: We thought we’d get a boy.
label: neutral

text: Matthew is getting up in years, you know--he’s sixty--and he isn’t so spry as he once was.
label: joy

text: His heart troubles him a good deal.
label: sadness

text: And you know how desperate hard it’s got to be to get hired help.
label: neutral

text: There’s never anybody to be had but those stupid, half-grown little French boys; and as soon as you do get one broke into your ways and taught something he’s up and off to the lobster canneries or the States.
label: neutral

text: At first Matthew suggested getting a Home boy.
label: neutral

text: But I said ‘no’ flat to that.
label: neutral

text: ‘They may be all right--I’m not saying they’re not--but no London street Arabs for me,’ I said.
label: neutral

text: ‘Give me a native born at least.
label: neutral

text: There’ll be a risk, no matter who we get.
label: neutral

text: But I’ll feel easier in my mind and sleep sounder at nights if we get a born Canadian.’ So in the end we decided to ask Mrs. Spencer to pick us out one when she went over to get her little girl.
label: disgust

text: We heard last week she was going, so we sent her word by Richard Spencer’s folks at Carmody to bring us a smart, likely boy of about ten or eleven.
label: neutral

text: We decided that would be the best age--old enough to be of some use in doing chores right off and young enough to be trained up proper.
label: neutral

text: We mean to give him a good home and schooling.
label: neutral

text: We had a telegram from Mrs. Alexander Spencer today--the mail-man brought it from the station--saying they were coming on the five-thirty train tonight.
label: neutral

text: So Matthew went to Bright River to meet him.
label: neutral

text: Mrs. Spencer will drop him off there.
label: neutral

text: Of course she goes on to White Sands station herself.”
label: neutral

text: Mrs. Rachel prided herself on always speaking her mind; she proceeded to speak it now, having adjusted her mental attitude to this amazing piece of news.
label: neutral

text: “Well, Marilla, I’ll just tell you plain that I think you’re doing a mighty foolish thing--a risky thing, that’s what.
label: neutral

text: You don’t know what you’re getting.
label: surprise

text: You’re bringing a strange child into your house and home and you don’t know a single thing about him nor what his disposition is like nor what sort of parents he had nor how he’s likely to turn out.
label: neutral

text: Why, it was only last week I read in the paper how a man and his wife up west of the Island took a boy out of an orphan asylum and he set fire to the house at night--set it _on purpose_, Marilla--and nearly burnt them to a crisp in their beds.
label: anger

text: And I know another case where an adopted boy used to suck the eggs--they couldn’t break him of it.
label: disgust

text: If you had asked my advice in the matter--which you didn’t do, Marilla--I’d have said for mercy’s sake not to think of such a thing, that’s what.”
label: neutral

text: This Job’s comforting seemed neither to offend nor to alarm Marilla.
label: anger

text: She knitted steadily on.
label: neutral

text: “I don’t deny there’s something in what you say, Rachel.
label: neutral

text: I’ve had some qualms myself.
label: fear

text: But Matthew was terrible set on it.
label: fear

text: I could see that, so I gave in.
label: anger

text: It’s so seldom Matthew sets his mind on anything that when he does I always feel it’s my duty to give in.
label: neutral

text: And as for the risk, there’s risks in pretty near everything a body does in this world.
label: neutral

text: There’s risks in people’s having children of their own if it comes to that--they don’t always turn out well.
label: neutral

text: And then Nova Scotia is right close to the Island.
label: neutral

text: It isn’t as if we were getting him from England or the States.
label: neutral

text: He can’t be much different from ourselves.”
label: neutral

text: “Well, I hope it will turn out all right,” said Mrs. Rachel in a tone that plainly indicated her painful doubts.
label: sadness

text: “Only don’t say I didn’t warn you if he burns Green Gables down or puts strychnine in the well--I heard of a case over in New Brunswick where an orphan asylum child did that and the whole family died in fearful agonies.
label: fear

text: Only, it was a girl in that instance.”
label: neutral

text: “Well, we’re not getting a girl,” said Marilla, as if poisoning wells were a purely feminine accomplishment and not to be dreaded in the case of a boy.
label: fear

text: “I’d never dream of taking a girl to bring up.
label: fear

text: I wonder at Mrs. Alexander Spencer for doing it.
label: surprise

text: But there, _she_ wouldn’t shrink from adopting a whole orphan asylum if she took it into her head.”
label: neutral

text: Mrs. Rachel would have liked to stay until Matthew came home with his imported orphan.
label: sadness

text: But reflecting that it would be a good two hours at least before his arrival she concluded to go up the road to Robert Bell’s and tell the news.
label: neutral

text: It would certainly make a sensation second to none, and Mrs. Rachel dearly loved to make a sensation.
label: joy

text: So she took herself away, somewhat to Marilla’s relief, for the latter felt her doubts and fears reviving under the influence of Mrs. Rachel’s pessimism.
label: sadness

text: “Well, of all things that ever were or will be!” ejaculated Mrs. Rachel when she was safely out in the lane.
label: neutral

text: “It does really seem as if I must be dreaming.
label: surprise

text: Well, I’m sorry for that poor young one and no mistake.
label: sadness

text: Matthew and Marilla don’t know anything about children and they’ll expect him to be wiser and steadier than his own grandfather, if so be’s he ever had a grandfather, which is doubtful.
label: neutral

text: It seems uncanny to think of a child at Green Gables somehow; there’s never been one there, for Matthew and Marilla were grown up when the new house was built--if they ever _were_ children, which is hard to believe when one looks at them.
label: surprise

text: I wouldn’t be in that orphan’s shoes for anything.
label: neutral

text: My, but I pity him, that’s what.”
label: disgust

text: So said Mrs. Rachel to the wild rose bushes out of the fulness of her heart; but if she could have seen the child who was waiting patiently at the Bright River station at that very moment her pity would have been still deeper and more profound.
label: neutral

text: CHAPTER II.
label: neutral

text: Matthew Cuthbert Is Surprised
label: surprise

text: MATTHEW Cuthbert and the sorrel mare jogged comfortably over the eight miles to Bright River.
label: neutral

text: It was a pretty road, running along between snug farmsteads, with now and again a bit of balsamy fir wood to drive through or a hollow where wild plums hung out their filmy bloom.
label: disgust

text: The air was sweet with the breath of many apple orchards and the meadows sloped away in the distance to horizon mists of pearl and purple; while
label: neutral

text: “The little birds sang as if it were      The one day of summer in all the year.”
label: joy

text: Matthew enjoyed the drive after his own fashion, except during the moments when he met women and had to nod to them--for in Prince Edward Island you are supposed to nod to all and sundry you meet on the road whether you know them or not.
label: neutral

text: Matthew dreaded all women except Marilla and Mrs. Rachel; he had an uncomfortable feeling that the mysterious creatures were secretly laughing at him.
label: fear

text: He may have been quite right in thinking so, for he was an odd-looking personage, with an ungainly figure and long iron-gray hair that touched his stooping shoulders, and a full, soft brown beard which he had worn ever since he was twenty.
label: neutral

text: In fact, he had looked at twenty very much as he looked at sixty, lacking a little of the grayness.
label: neutral

text: When he reached Bright River there was no sign of any train; he thought he was too early, so he tied his horse in the yard of the small Bright River hotel and went over to the station house.
label: neutral

text: The long platform was almost deserted; the only living creature in sight being a girl who was sitting on a pile of shingles at the extreme end.
label: disgust

text: Matthew, barely noting that it _was_ a girl, sidled past her as quickly as possible without looking at her.
label: neutral

text: Had he looked he could hardly have failed to notice the tense rigidity and expectation of her attitude and expression.
label: neutral

text: She was sitting there waiting for something or somebody and, since sitting and waiting was the only thing to do just then, she sat and waited with all her might and main.
label: neutral

text: Matthew encountered the stationmaster locking up the ticket office preparatory to going home for supper, and asked him if the five-thirty train would soon be along.
label: neutral

text: “The five-thirty train has been in and gone half an hour ago,” answered that brisk official.
label: neutral

text: “But there was a passenger dropped off for you--a little girl.
label: surprise

text: She’s sitting out there on the shingles.
label: disgust

text: I asked her to go into the ladies’ waiting room, but she informed me gravely that she preferred to stay outside.
label: sadness

text: ‘There was more scope for imagination,’ she said.
label: neutral

text: She’s a case, I should say.”
label: neutral

text: “I’m not expecting a girl,” said Matthew blankly.
label: sadness

text: “It’s a boy I’ve come for.
label: neutral

text: He should be here.
label: neutral

text: Mrs. Alexander Spencer was to bring him over from Nova Scotia for me.”
label: neutral

text: The stationmaster whistled.
label: neutral

text: “Guess there’s some mistake,” he said.
label: neutral

text: “Mrs.
label: neutral

text: Spencer came off the train with that girl and gave her into my charge.
label: anger

text: Said you and your sister were adopting her from an orphan asylum and that you would be along for her presently.
label: neutral

text: That’s all I know about it--and I haven’t got any more orphans concealed hereabouts.”
label: neutral

text: “I don’t understand,” said Matthew helplessly, wishing that Marilla was at hand to cope with the situation.
label: fear

text: “Well, you’d better question the girl,” said the stationmaster carelessly.
label: neutral

text: “I dare say she’ll be able to explain--she’s got a tongue of her own, that’s certain.
label: disgust

text: Maybe they were out of boys of the brand you wanted.”
label: neutral

text: He walked jauntily away, being hungry, and the unfortunate Matthew was left to do that which was harder for him than bearding a lion in its den--walk up to a girl--a strange girl--an orphan girl--and demand of her why she wasn’t a boy.
label: fear

text: Matthew groaned in spirit as he turned about and shuffled gently down the platform towards her.
label: disgust

text: She had been watching him ever since he had passed her and she had her eyes on him now.
label: disgust

text: Matthew was not looking at her and would not have seen what she was really like if he had been, but an ordinary observer would have seen this: A child of about eleven, garbed in a very short, very tight, very ugly dress of yellowish-gray wincey.
label: neutral

text: She wore a faded brown sailor hat and beneath the hat, extending down her back, were two braids of very thick, decidedly red hair.
label: disgust

text: Her face was small, white and thin, also much freckled; her mouth was large and so were her eyes, which looked green in some lights and moods and gray in others.
label: disgust

text: So far, the ordinary observer; an extraordinary observer might have seen that the chin was very pointed and pronounced; that the big eyes were full of spirit and vivacity; that the mouth was sweet-lipped and expressive; that the forehead was broad and full; in short, our discerning extraordinary observer might have concluded that no commonplace soul inhabited the body of this stray woman-child of whom shy Matthew Cuthbert was so ludicrously afraid.
label: neutral

text: Matthew, however, was spared the ordeal of speaking first, for as soon as she concluded that he was coming to her she stood up, grasping with one thin brown hand the handle of a shabby, old-fashioned carpet-bag; the other she held out to him.
label: disgust

text: “I suppose you are Mr. Matthew Cuthbert of Green Gables?” she said in a peculiarly clear, sweet voice.
label: neutral

text: “I’m very glad to see you.
label: joy

text: I was beginning to be afraid you weren’t coming for me and I was imagining all the things that might have happened to prevent you.
label: fear

text: I had made up my mind that if you didn’t come for me tonight I’d go down the track to that big wild cherry-tree at the bend, and climb up into it to stay all night.
label: neutral

text: I wouldn’t be a bit afraid, and it would be lovely to sleep in a wild cherry-tree all white with bloom in the moonshine, don’t you think?
label: fear

text: You could imagine you were dwelling in marble halls, couldn’t you?
label: surprise

text: And I was quite sure you would come for me in the morning, if you didn’t tonight.”
label: neutral

text: Matthew had taken the scrawny little hand awkwardly in his; then and there he decided what to do.
label: neutral

text: He could not tell this child with the glowing eyes that there had been a mistake; he would take her home and let Marilla do that.
label: neutral

text: She couldn’t be left at Bright River anyhow, no matter what mistake had been made, so all questions and explanations might as well be deferred until he was safely back at Green Gables.
label: neutral

text: “I’m sorry I was late,” he said shyly.
label: fear

text: “Come along.
label: neutral

label: disgust

label: neutral

label: joy

label: neutral

label: neutral

label: neutral

label: surprise

label: disgust

label: disgust

text: They were good, you know--the asylum people.
label: joy

text: But there is so little scope for the imagination in an asylum--only just in the other orphans.
label: neutral

text: It was pretty interesting to imagine things about them--to imagine that perhaps the girl who sat next to you was really the daughter of a belted earl, who had been stolen away from her parents in her infancy by a cruel nurse who died before she could confess.
label: disgust

text: I used to lie awake at nights and imagine things like that, because I didn’t have time in the day.
label: neutral

text: I guess that’s why I’m so thin--I _am_ dreadful thin, ain’t I?
label: fear

text: There isn’t a pick on my bones.
label: neutral

text: I do love to imagine I’m nice and plump, with dimples in my elbows.”
label: joy

text: With this Matthew’s companion stopped talking, partly because she was out of breath and partly because they had reached the buggy.
label: disgust

text: Not another word did she say until they had left the village and were driving down a steep little hill, the road part of which had been cut so deeply into the soft soil that the banks, fringed with blooming wild cherry-trees and slim white birches, were several feet above their heads.
label: neutral

text: The child put out her hand and broke off a branch of wild plum that brushed against the side of the buggy.
label: disgust

text: “Isn’t that beautiful?
label: surprise

text: What did that tree, leaning out from the bank, all white and lacy, make you think of?” she asked.
label: neutral

text: “Well now, I dunno,” said Matthew.
label: neutral

text: “Why, a bride, of course--a bride all in white with a lovely misty veil.
label: surprise

text: I’ve never seen one, but I can imagine what she would look like.
label: surprise

text: I don’t ever expect to be a bride myself.
label: surprise

label: neutral

label: neutral

label: neutral

label: joy

label: joy

text: And I’ve never had a pretty dress in my life that I can remember--but of course it’s all the more to look forward to, isn’t it?
label: surprise

text: And then I can imagine that I’m dressed gorgeously.
label: joy

text: This morning when I left the asylum I felt so ashamed because I had to wear this horrid old wincey dress.
label: fear

text: All the orphans had to wear them, you know.
label: neutral

text: A merchant in Hopeton last winter donated three hundred yards of wincey to the asylum.

text: Two days afterwards they carried Matthew Cuthbert over his homestead threshold and away from the fields he had tilled and the orchards he had loved and the trees he had planted; and then Avonlea settled back to its usual placidity and even at Green Gables affairs slipped into their old groove and work was done and duties fulfilled with regularity as before, although always with the aching sense of “loss in all familiar things.”  Anne, new to grief, thought it almost sad that it could be so--that they _could_ go on in the old way without Matthew.
label: neutral

text: She felt something like shame and remorse when she discovered that the sunrises behind the firs and the pale pink buds opening in the garden gave her the old inrush of gladness when she saw them--that Diana’s visits were pleasant to her and that Diana’s merry words and ways moved her to laughter and smiles--that, in brief, the beautiful world of blossom and love and friendship had lost none of its power to please her fancy and thrill her heart, that life still called to her with many insistent voices.

text: Anne went to the little Avonlea graveyard the next evening to put fresh flowers on Matthew’s grave and water the Scotch rosebush.
label: disgust

text: She lingered there until dusk, liking the peace and calm of the little place, with its poplars whose rustle was like low, friendly speech, and its whispering grasses growing at will among the graves.
label: joy

text: When she finally left it and walked down the long hill that sloped to the Lake of Shining Waters it was past sunset and all Avonlea lay before her in a dreamlike afterlight--“a haunt of ancient peace.” There was a freshness in the air as of a wind that had blown over honey-sweet fields of clover.
label: fear

text: Home lights twinkled out here and there among the homestead trees.
label: neutral

text: Beyond lay the sea, misty and purple, with its haunting, unceasing murmur.
label: fear

text: The west was a glory of soft mingled hues, and the pond reflected them all in still softer shadings.
label: neutral

text: The beauty of it all thrilled Anne’s heart, and she gratefully opened the gates of her soul to it.
label: joy

text: “Dear old world,” she murmured, “you are very lovely, and I am glad to be alive in you.”
label: joy

text: Halfway down the hill a tall lad came whistling out of a gate before the Blythe homestead.

text: It was Gilbert, and the whistle died on his lips as he recognized Anne.

text: He lifted his cap courteously, but he would have passed on in silence, if Anne had not stopped and held out her hand.
label: disgust

text: “Gilbert,” she said, with scarlet cheeks, “I want to thank you for giving up the school for me.
label: sadness

text: It was very good of you--and I want you to know that I appreciate it.”

text: Gilbert took the offered hand eagerly.

text: “It wasn’t particularly good of me at all, Anne.

text: I was pleased to be able to do you some small service.

text: Have you really forgiven me my old fault?”

text: Anne laughed and tried unsuccessfully to withdraw her hand.

text: “I forgave you that day by the pond landing, although I didn’t know it.

text: What a stubborn little goose I was.

text: I’ve been--I may as well make a complete confession--I’ve been sorry ever since.”

text: “We are going to be the best of friends,” said Gilbert, jubilantly.

text: “We were born to be good friends, Anne.

text: You’ve thwarted destiny enough.

text: I know we can help each other in many ways.

text: Marilla looked curiously at Anne when the latter entered the kitchen.

text: “Who was that came up the lane with you, Anne?”

text: “Gilbert Blythe,” answered Anne, vexed to find herself blushing.

text: “I met him on Barry’s hill.”

text: “I didn’t think you and Gilbert Blythe were such good friends that you’d stand for half an hour at the gate talking to him,” said Marilla with a dry smile.

text: “We haven’t been--we’ve been good enemies.

text: It seemed just a few minutes.

text: But, you see, we have five years’ lost conversations to catch up with, Marilla.”

text: Anne sat long at her window that night companioned by a glad content.
label: joy

text: The wind purred softly in the cherry boughs, and the mint breaths came up to her.

text: The stars twinkled over the pointed firs in the hollow and Diana’s light gleamed through the old gap.
label: neutral

text: Anne’s horizons had closed in since the night she had sat there after coming home from Queen’s; but if the path set before her feet was to be narrow she knew that flowers of quiet happiness would bloom along it.
label: joy

text: The joy of sincere work and worthy aspiration and congenial friendship were to be hers; nothing could rob her of her birthright of fancy or her ideal world of dreams.
label: joy

text: And there was always the bend in the road!

text: “‘God’s in his heaven, all’s right with the world,’” whispered Anne softly.
